skill.name: ghe-design
skill.description: Reference material for Athena when writing requirements. NOT a template - Athena writes requirements freely based on the domain. This skill provides guidance patterns that may be useful, not constraints to follow.
skill.summary: Design requirements guidance for Athena agent
skill.author: Emasoft

security_audit.summary: All static findings evaluated as false positives. The skill is pure documentation containing example code patterns and references to external resources. Backticks are markdown formatting, not shell execution. URLs are legitimate documentation links. Cryptography references (bcrypt, RS256, UUID v4) are strong algorithms, not weak ones. No actual code execution, network calls, or filesystem operations exist in this skill.

content.value_statement: Users struggle to write clear, verifiable requirements. This skill provides guidance patterns for different domains so Athena can produce requirements documents that developers can implement without ambiguity.
actual_capabilities: Provides guidance patterns for requirements across domains (mathematical, game mechanics, financial, distributed systems, security)
Teaches free-form requirements structure instead of rigid templates
Shows how to write domain-appropriate language in requirements
Demonstrates external reference linking instead of copy-pasting
Covers minimum viable requirements for simple features
limitations: This is reference material only, not an automated requirements generator
Does not execute any code or make network calls
Does not interface with external systems or APIs

use_cases.title: Writing technical specifications
use_cases.description: Use mathematical notation, state machines, or formal proofs when writing requirements for algorithms or systems that require precise technical documentation.
use_cases.target_user: Technical product managers and system architects

use_cases.title: Creating game or interactive system requirements
use_cases.description: Structure requirements for game mechanics using state transitions, physics parameters, and verifiable feel requirements.
use_cases.target_user: Game designers and interactive media developers

use_cases.title: Documenting security or compliance requirements
use_cases.description: Write requirements with threat models, trust boundaries, and regulatory compliance specifications for security-sensitive features.

prompt_templates.title: Basic requirements request
prompt_templates.prompt: Write requirements for [feature description]. Include what is being built, why it is needed, and acceptance criteria that can be verified.
prompt_templates.scenario: Starting a new feature that needs clear specifications

prompt_templates.title: Domain-specific requirements
prompt_templates.prompt: Write requirements for [feature description] using [domain pattern - mathematical/game mechanics/financial/security/distributed]. Follow the pattern shown in ghe-design skill for this domain.
prompt_templates.scenario: Needing requirements in a specific domain with appropriate structure

prompt_templates.title: Requirements with verification
prompt_templates.prompt: Write complete requirements for [feature description] including: identification (REQ-XXX), what, why, verifiable acceptance criteria, and external references. Domain is [domain].

prompt_templates.title: Performance-aware requirements
prompt_templates.prompt: Write requirements for [feature description]. Include performance considerations that should be deferred until the feature works. List known optimization considerations for the future.

best_practices: Structure requirements around domain-specific patterns (math notation for algorithms, state diagrams for interactive systems, legal language for compliance)
Include verifiable acceptance criteria that can be tested - avoid vague statements like 'works correctly'
Reference external documentation rather than copying entire RFCs or API specifications
anti_patterns: Using rigid templates for every domain - different domains need different structures
Writing requirements that answer 'how' instead of 'what' - let developers choose implementation
Skipping acceptance criteria or writing them as vague quality statements instead of testable conditions

faq.question: Is this skill a template I must follow exactly?
faq.answer: No. The patterns in this skill are references, not constraints. Each domain has unique needs. Use what serves the domain, ignore what does not apply, add what is missing.

faq.question: What must every requirements document include?
faq.answer: Every document must include: clear identification (REQ-NNN with version), what is being built (unambiguous description), why it is needed (user story or justification), how to verify completion (testable acceptance criteria), and external references (links to APIs, specs, assets).

faq.question: How should I handle performance requirements?
faq.answer: Defer performance targets until the feature works. Specify WHAT, not HOW FAST. Add targets only when profiling reveals actual bottlenecks. Document known considerations for future optimization.

faq.question: Can I copy-paste from external documentation?
faq.answer: No. Link to external documentation, specifications, and standards. Do not copy entire RFCs or API docs. This keeps requirements documents concise and ensures users always have the latest information.

faq.question: What makes requirements verifiable?
faq.answer: Verifiable requirements have concrete, testable outcomes. Instead of 'returns quickly,' use 'returns HTTP 200 within 200ms.' Instead of 'handles errors,' use 'logs error with context and returns 500 to client.'

faq.question: How do I write requirements for different domains?
faq.answer: Match the language to the domain. Use mathematical notation for algorithms, state diagrams for interactive systems, legal language for compliance, network diagrams for distributed systems, and entity relationships for data models.
